captions.text: A note on friends and friendship:
I come in contact with a lot of bodies and handshakes and smiles and laughter and friendly moments,
but a friend is something different.
Making a friend...
Is it making or allowing, I don't know.
There's been a lot of different ways that it started and some of them seem pretty vague;
sometimes it's been a smile that I didn't expect and didn't know I needed,
sometimes it's been a slow build, sometimes a chase,
but there's usually a moment where comes into focus;
a pat on the back, an invitation, a secret; and then there it is, I have a friend.
I can kinda feel that moment on my face, it's like I'm trying to hold my mouth in place.
Like a smile, but I don't wanna react too much; I don't wanna ruin it.
And a flush, maybe of fear. I can be pretty awkward sometimes, especially if I give a shit.
I don't know why, exactly, but talking about this makes me sad.
Maybe it's because when I look harder at something so essential I get scared by how much I've overlooked or neglected it.
There's some things that I care about much less but I pay a lot more attention to,
and it's a reminder to change that.
So thank you.
Thank you for thinking of me,
for reserving part of your mind for things like my birthday or the books that I like to read.
Thank you for not hurting me,
despite being in a position to hurt me much more than most people could.
Thank you for inviting me to things and including me on email lists with your other friends,
some of which I do get jealous of from time to time.
You'll forgive me for that, I hope.
I just wonder where I stand in relation to them sometimes,
and in some moments I've even thought of myself as above you, or beneath you, and I apologize for both.
Maybe the greatest gift you give me is allowing me to stop struggling to find my place.
We're friends; that is the place.
It's an extension of what I call home.
As we've gotten older, your face still looks the same to me.
After not seeing you for a while I might notice some small change in your hair, or a new mole,
but to me your face isn't in those details.
It's in the movement, the pacing.
And that's sort of what defines us as friends, too,
not our bodies, not the jobs we have, but the movement.
The way we follow and hopscotch each other's ideas, the way you wait for me to catch up with a thought,
the occasional apology; I can be a dick sometimes, I know that.
That rhythm of separation and closeness, the reminders that you aren't me,
which is good, because I'm not such a good friend to me.
And that overlapping phone call that relieves the shared tension of too much time gone by.
It ebbs and flows, though, I know that.
There might be times where we become parodies of our past selves,
just skimming on the surface with snippets of old conversations,
pretending that the disconnect is the same thing as the comfortable but active silence that sometimes we've enjoyed.
And if it goes on too long, one of us is gonna have to have the courage to speak up,
and the other one's gonna have to have the courage to respond.
I've watched some of my friendships fade out of the corner of my eye,
and I don't want that to happen with you.
It's a kind of love, by the way.
It's awkward to say that, but it is.
Not as binding in the day-to-day as love for lovers, but it has the same responsibilities,
and I need to remind myself of that from time to time,
so thank you for being my friend.
Bye bye bye, it's the bye-bye song.

comments.text:
Just to note, Ze hasn't done an 'a show' type show in 11 months. I love Ze 
but it's hard to listen to a friend say 'I don't want to let our friendship 
fade' and then he goes and lets the friendship fade.

At least with this relationship, we can go back and watch the old videos, 
instead of having to rely on the bits and pieces we remember.﻿
comments.author: Mick Mickymick

comments.text:
I enjoy making and hearing laughter so a friend or friends are important. 
They tend to be the strength you don't have or the knowledge you can't 
find. Knowing a friend is a great relief and a constant source of pride, 
joy and happiness kind of life a breath of fresh air. I think if you get 
along with yourself, you can get along with others. A friend might just be 
someone you share life with, short term or long term. Friends are 
important, that's why I used so many words. Just don't count your friends, 
it is an awful exercise. ﻿
comments.author: Alexander Weaver

comments.text:
At First Sight
by Robert Graves
(1895-1985)
'Love at first sight,' some say, misnaming
Discovery of twinned helplessness
Against the huge tug of procreation.
But friendship at first sight? This also
Catches fiercely at the surprised heart
So that the cheek blanches and then blushes.﻿

comments.author: Miz

comments.text:
This is definitely my favorite video. I would love to see a similar video 
for family. And I don't mean blood relatives necessarily but "friends" that 
become such a part of your life that they are your family. My mother died 
while I was still in college. I finished EMT school and was in the fire 
academy. She was my first patient as an EMT. Then I lost all my cousins and 
aunts and uncles too. I was still a young kid and never had to take care of 
myself before. A lady who I used to fence with took me under her wing and 
eventually adopted me. Maybe not in the form of a "legal" adoption but she 
took me into her home as one of her own. Every holiday. Every vacation is 
spent with her. With her only being 10 years older than me we decided she 
couldn't be "mom" but more like my sister. Ever since she and a small group 
of other people she also has "adopted" became my family. And this video is 
everything I would love to say to them but I would still like to see a 
"family" version﻿
comments.author: Woohoodude989

comments.text:
+zefrank1 Hey ze, you probably won't ever read this, and the act of me 
typing this and expecting you to actually read and respond to it is 
probably going to be like me trying to talk to that white bearded son of a 
bitch in that imaginary cloud fantasy land. I am a loner by default and I 
fucking hate it. Teenagers are by default talk and act selfish little 
bastards and ever since high school I've been digging a deeper and deeper 
hole into myself because I was always terrible at talking and acting like a 
selfish little bastard. In other words, I was always the guy in the group 
who didn't want to get under anybody's skin. I came to the conclusion that 
friends are bullshit. It's my third year of college and I've never felt 
more alone and isolated. I want to break the cycle but have no idea how. If 
you could offer me some tips or even just read and respond to this rant, I 
would appreciate it. ﻿
comments.author: Kermicheo Kermit

comments.text: +Kermicheo Kermit Mhm,no problem.
comments.author: Ghostface Killah

comments.text: +DB tHa MC thank you for the advice. I'll try it.
comments.author: Kermicheo Kermit

comments.text:
Dude,believe it or not,I'm a little bit of the same way. I get bored with 
everyone else because they like what I like,but not enough to make it seem 
like they actually appreciate it.I regularly go to music whenever I feel 
alone,I overthink practically every little thought or occurance that I 
experience,I've found that going to a social network and jumping into a 
group or community about something you like helps with meeting new people.I 
know it's worked for me,like,really well.I'm terrible at talking 
too,but,once I find someone I can talk to,I just go on and on and on until 
they leave the convo,lol.I've also found that being more chilled 
out,calm,and open-minded makes you less of an introvert,but more of an 
ambivert,a mix between an introvert and an extrovert.Once you become 
open-minded,you feel soooo much less of a loner,and more of a group 
person,that's how I  am,but I'm still a little bit of an introvert,as in,I 
need time alone to recharge,music helps me more than anything,etc. etc. 
But,yeah,finding a community helps out gigantically,my friend.
comments.author: Ghostface Killah

comments.text:
Believe me when i say that 'cool' kids want a real and down to earth friend 
too. Not really 'people' of their level. Moving forward i recommend you 
watch peakyourmind's video on how to make friends. He is citing from a 
known book called How to win friends and influence others. The things 
aren't even rocket science, just common sense. Good luck!

comments.author: Miz

comments.text:
"I came to the conclusion that friends are bullshit."

Well, there's your problem. Maybe just haven't found the right people yet? 
:3

And no need to worry about focusing on making friends as such, just talk to 
people in general, see what happens. And the more polite/lively you are 
towards them, the more they will be in return likewise. As someone 
approaching you with the preconceived idea of 'you are bullshit' doesn't 
sound like very fun company.

There's usually quite a bit of insecurity and weird shit going on around 
the teenage years though, and everyone fucks up now and then, just take it 
easy is all and don't worry \o/

comments.text:
I don't necessarily have much left to say socially anymore It seems. I feel 
I'd much rather keep a majority of my thoughts to myself. Maybe it's a 
phase, or maybe it's the disenchantment with technology. The hermit in me 
has become a recluse to the digital world and I've mostly become a ghost 
leaving my past identity behind. This shouldn't be construed as giving up 
on family or friends (although it feels like this past year there has been 
quite a few that have given up on me). Whether that's the case or not and 
whether we speak an hour from now or never again.....
Thanks.﻿
